results.title: Repairing a window pane
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Repairs in the Home”.
A practical demonstration of replacing a broken window pane. The film shows the tools required for the job and the whole process in order of procedure, taking out the sash of an upstairs window, measuring the pane, removing the old putty from the rebate and painting the bare wood exposed and fixing the new glass with putty.

results.title: Repairing a sashcord
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Repairs in the Home”.
A practical demonstration of replacing a broken sashcord. An introductory sequence explains the difference between casement and sliding sash windows. A working model shows the structure of the latter. A man is seen in an upstairs room at work renewing a broken sashcord. Each stage of the job is illustrated in detail. Finally the film shows the tools which were used and summarises the method.

results.title: Renmark on the river
results.creator_credit: G Shepherd and South Australian Government Tourist Bureau
results.brief_description: Presents Renmark as Australia’s first irrigation settlement. Introduces the Renmark Trust utilizing the waters of the Murray River to irrigate fruit trees and vines. We see oranges prepared for market whilst other fruits include apricots, peaches, pears, lemons and grapefruit; and vineyards produce sultanas, raisins, and grapes for wine making. The scenic attractions of the River and town are also seen.

results.title: Rene Spitz: about his own work
results.creator_credit: Susan Sussman and Parents' Magazine Films
results.brief_description: A professional portrait of Dr. Rene Spitz, paediatrician and psychiatrist, largely based on footage taken on a visit to the Erikson Institute in Chicago, 1969. Dr. Spitz is best known for his work on the effects of emotional deprivation on children.
results.description: A professional portrait of Dr. Rene Spitz, paediatrician and psychiatrist, largely based on footage taken on a visit to the Erikson Institute in Chicago, 1969. Dr. Spitz is best known for his work on the effects of emotional deprivation on children.

results.title: Rendezvous with destiny
results.creator_credit: Harold Mayer and United States Information Agency
results.brief_description: This film strikingly conveys the destitution and despair of the depression of the 1930’s in the U.S. which gave rise to the election of Franklin D. Roosevelt and the “New Deal”. Footage shows dumping of milk to raise prices, children sleeping in the street, people living on the city dump, the march of people to Washington, troops attacking peaceful marchers, the right to organise unions and footage of striking workers at Ford with police firing on strikers. Written by Harold Flender. Narrated by Michael Tolan.

results.title: Rendezvous
results.brief_description: This experimental film with no dialogue was shot without photographic tricks nor changes in camera speed. The camera is inside a speeding motor car as the filmmaker films en route to a rendezvous with his wife in Paris.

results.title: Remodelling milk
results.brief_description: Australian research into the behaviour of milk proteins during heating and mixing has led to new techniques for processing stable skim-milk powders rich in protein. This powder can be transported relatively cheaply to recombining plants in tropical areas, where it is mixed with anhydrous milk fat and water, with or without sugar, to produce sweetened condensed milk or unsweetened evaporated milk. Traces the recombining techniques from pilot plant to full-scale commercial production.

results.title: Remembrance: Reverberation [exhibition documentation]
results.brief_description:
“Remembrance: Reverberation” was an exhibition held at ACMI Screen Gallery, 27 June 2003 - 31 August 2003. See Exhibition activity file record “Remembrance: Reverberation” (ID 12) for more information.
Are memories like movies? Can they be recorded? Can you capture their yearning, their dread, their jubilation? Featuring spellbinding artworks by leading artists from around the world in ACMI’s acclaimed screen gallery, Remembrance reveals how deeply our memories can move us.

An unforgettable experience that draws on the visitors’ own memories, Remembrance will affect everyone in unique and unexpected ways. Evoking and challenging the intimate memories that sustain and shape our past, present and future, Remembrance immerses the visitor in explorations from the romantic to the confessional, from the spiritual to the taboo.
